title: Trump and Putin to Meet in 'Coming Days,' Kremlin Aide Confirms
description: President Vladimir Putin of Russia has agreed to meet with President Donald Trump "in the coming day...
content:
President Vladimir Putin of Russia has agreed to meet with President Donald Trump “in the coming days,” a top Kremlin aide said Thursday, as the White House pushes for a ceasefire in Ukraine.

The aide, Yuri Ushakov, Putin’s foreign policy adviser, confirmed reports Wednesday that Trump said he planned to meet the Russian leader in person as soon as next week and to follow up with a meeting with Putin and President Volodymyr Zelenskyy of Ukraine.

“The American side has suggested, and we have agreed in principle, to hold a high-level bilateral meeting, that is, a meeting between Presidents Vladimir Putin and Donald Trump,” Ushakov told Russian news agencies Thursday. He declined to discuss the idea of a three-way summit with Zelenskyy.

Ushakov did not give an exact date for the meeting, saying only that it was “hard to say how much time the preparations for such an important meeting would take.” Russia and the United States have agreed on the place to meet but will not be disclosing it at this time, Ushakov added.

The confirmation of a potential sit-down between the American and Russian leaders comes a day after Steve Witkoff, Trump’s envoy, held talks with Putin at the Kremlin.

It was the latest in a flurry of diplomatic activity since the White House issued an ultimatum for Russia: Either agree to a ceasefire in Ukraine or face new sanctions.

Meeting with Trump would be something of another minor victory for Putin, who had been largely isolated by NATO leaders over the invasion of Ukraine until Trump started phone conversations with the Russian leader after coming to office.

If the meeting goes ahead, it would be the first in-person summit between an American and Russian president in more than four years.

This article originally appeared in The New York Times.
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin has agreed to meet with President Donald Trump in the coming days, according to a top Kremlin aide. This comes as the White House continues to push for a ceasefire in Ukraine. The meeting, if confirmed, would be the first in-person summit between an American and Russian president in over four years. The White House and Russia have agreed on the location for the meeting, but will not be disclosing it. The confirmation comes after a day of discussions between Trump's envoy Steve Witkoff and Putin at the Kremlin.
